Currently, restricting the formation of CO and paraffin by-products at mild reaction conditions, and avoiding the waste of carbon resources remain challenging for CO2 hydrogenation into light olefins. Herein, we constructed a bifunctional catalyst consisting of Zn0.3Ce0.2Zr1.8O4 solid solution and SAPO-34 zeolite. The catalyst shows excellent performance with a high C2 = – C4 = selectivity of 90.1% and an O/P ratio of 60.1 at a CO2 conversion of 6.0% at 280 ºC and 0.5 MPa, while the selectivity of CO is only 7.9%. Various characterization and designed experiment results demonstrate that incorporating appropriate amounts of Ce in Zn0.3ZrOx generates more oxygen vacancies that improve CO2 activation to form formate and methoxy intermediates at low temperature and pressure. This promotes the evolution of these intermediates into light olefins over the SAPO-34 zeolite, enhancing the overall capacity of the bifunctional Zn0.3Ce0.2Zr1.8O4/SAPO-34 composited catalyst in CO2 hydrogenation under mild conditions. Graphical Abstract The construction of a bifunctional catalyst consisting of zinc-cerium zirconium (Zn0.3Ce0.2Zr1.8O4) solid solution and SAPO-34 zeolite and its excellent catalytic performance for CO2 hydrogenation at mild reaction condition. ga1 Keywords CO2 hydrogenation Light olefins Bifunctional catalyst Low temperature and low pressure Reaction mechanism Data Availability The authors do not have permission to share data. 1 Introduction The excessive use of fossil fuels leads to the massive release of CO2, which causes serious greenhouse effects and global climate warming [1,2]. Since CO2 is a non-toxic, abundant and renewable carbon source, utilizing it as a feedstock for producing basic chemicals is not only beneficial for alleviating climate changes caused by increasing CO2 emissions but also reduces our over-reliance on fossil fuels [3,4]. Among them, CO2 hydrogenation to light olefins (C2 =–C4 =) is a promising route for directly converting CO2 into valuable chemicals and has attracted considerable attention [5–13]. CO2 hydrogenation to light olefins can be achieved through the methanol-mediate bifunctional catalyst, where methanol is first formed over metal oxide, and then the conversion of methanol into light olefins (MTO) occurs over acidic zeolite [14–17]. It was found that the C2 = – C4 = selectivity can reach around 80 − 90% in hydrocarbons over the bifunctional catalysts such as In2O3/ZrO2–SAPO-34, In2O3-ZnZrOx/SAPO-34 or In2O3-ZrO2/SAPO-34 [18–20]. However, the fraction of undesired CO still reaches 50 − 90% with an olefin/paraffin (O/P) ratio of only 5 − 15, as relatively harsh reaction conditions (≥ 370 ºC and ≥ 2.0 MPa) were used for these bifunctional catalysts, significantly promoting the reverse water-gas shift (RWGS) reaction and over-hydrogenation of olefins. Therefore, many efforts have been devoted to inhibiting CO formation. ZnGa2O4/SAPO-34 fabricated by Wang’s group achieved a C2 =–C4 = selectivity in hydrocarbons of ∼87%, while decreasing CO selectivity to 41–44% [21]. The CO selectivity was found to be lower than 47% without decreasing the selectivity for lower olefins over ZnZrO/SAPO [22]. Recently, Fan’s group also developed a ZnCeZrO/RUB-13 bifunctional catalysts [23], which shows that the selectivity of CO was suppressed to 26.5% with production of much more propene and butene than ethene at 350 ℃ and 3.5 MPa by incorporating Ce into ZnZrOx and regulating acid site strength and distribution of H-RUB-13. Nevertheless, the C2 =–C4 = selectivity was decreased to 72.7%. The mass formation of CO and paraffin without further conversion results in an enormous waste of carbon resources. Therefore, it is urgent to design and develop a more efficient catalytic material that can be operated under mild conditions to inhibit the formation of CO and paraffin while simultaneously maintaining high selectivity of C2 = – C4 = and a high ratio of O/P. Lowering the reaction temperature has been confirmed to alleviate the hydrogenation of light olefins to alkanes, as well as restricting the RWGS reaction or decrease CO selectivity. Current research has shown that Cerium zirconium solid solution oxide (CeZrOx) and ZnZrOx have the potential to activate CO/CO2 due to the presence of abundant surface oxygen vacancies [24–26], allowing for simple recycling of the tail gas containing CO to enhance the yields of olefins. Furthermore, Zn has been proven to be capable of activating H2 [27]. Since oxygen vacancies over metal oxides have been widely considered active sites for CO2 activation [27–29], the challenge lies in increasing their amount affected by the crystal morphology and the composition of the surface. In this context, a series of ZnmCeyZr2−yOx solid solution nanoparticles (NPs) are prepared, and Zn0.3Ce0.2Zr1.8O4 solid solution with a high concentration of oxygen vacancies shows excellent catalytic performance for the direct conversion of CO2 into light olefins under mild reaction conditions after being coupled with SAPO-34 zeolite with proper acid density and acid strength. The selectivity for C2 = – C4 = and O/P ratio reaches as high as 90.1% and 60.1, respectively, with CO2 conversion of 6.0% at 280 ºC and 0.5 MPa. More excitingly, this composite gives comparable C2 =–C4 = yield to previously reported catalysts but with a much lower CO selectivity of only 7.9%. 2 Experiment 2.1 Catalyst preparation All ZnCeZrOx catalysts were synthesized using the sol-gel synthesis method. Typically, predetermined amounts of zinc nitrates (Zn(NO3)2•6 H2O), cerium nitrates (Ce(NO3)3•6 H2O) and zirconium nitrates (Zr(NO3)4•5 H2O) were first mixed in deionized water (200 mL) and stirred at 30 °C for 2 h, the molar ratio of Zr: Ce: Zn was n: 2-n: m (0 < n ≤ 2, 0 <m≤1). The glucose was then added to the mixed solution at 100 °C and vigorously stirred for at least 12 h. The molar ratio of glucose to the total metal ion in the solution was 3.0:1.0. The obtained colloid was dried at 100 °C for 12 h, and calcined at 300 °C for 1 h and 500 °C for 3 h in air. The SAPO-34 (CHA) zeolite was synthesized using the hydrothermal method. The synthetic material, including pseudo-boehmite (Al2O3), phosphoric acid (H3PO4), silica sol (JN-40), and tetraethyl ammonium hydroxide (TEAOH), were mixed in deionized water and stirred at room temperature for 3 h. The gel composition was 2.0TEAOH: xSiO2: 1.0Al2O3: 1.0 P2O5: 70 H2O (x = 0.05, 0.15 and 0.30). The synthesis gel was crystallized in a Teﬂon-lined stainless steel autoclave under rotation conditions at 200 °C for 24 h. The H-SAPO-34 was obtained by calcining the as-synthesized sample at 550 °C for 10 h in air. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The Catalysts were characterized using various techniques, including X-ray diﬀraction (XRD), field emission-scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM) images, transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high-resolution TEM (HRTEM), scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM), N2 sorption, temperature-programmed desorption of CO2 (CO2-TPD) or NH3 (NH3-TPD), temperature-programmed reduction by hydrogen (H2-TPR), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectra (DRIFTS), gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS), and 12C/13C methanol switching experiment. Further details about the catalyst characterizations are shown in Supplemental Experimental Procedure. 2.3 Catalyst evaluation CO2 conversion was conducted in a ﬁxed-bed reactor. The catalyst was loaded into a stainless steel tube with an inner diameter of 10 mm. Additional details about the catalyst evaluation and calculation equations are shown in Supplemental Experimental Procedure. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization The XRD analysis presented in Fig. 1 reveals the crystalline structures of the ZnCeZrOx solid solution catalysts. Six diffraction peaks at 30.5º, 35.1º, 50.4º, 59.8º, 74.4º and 82.1º can be assigned to (011), (002), (112), (121), (022), and (220) crystal facets of the tetragonal-structured CeZrO4 (JCPDS NO. 82–1398), respectively. No ZnO phase is detected in any of the solid solution catalysts with a Zn/(Ce+Zr) ratio ≤ 0.3 (Fig. 1). Further addition of Zn species is found to be unable to insert into the lattice sites and instead adheres to the sample surface. The mean sizes of obtained NPs, as calculated by the Scherrer equation, are about 5.0 nm (Table S1). The specific surface area and the pore volume of ZnxCe0.2Zr1.8O4 solid solutions fell within the range of 54.9–81.9 m2 g−1 and 0.074–0.111 cm3 g−1, respectively (Fig. S1 and Table S1). The HRTEM reveals interplanar spacings of 0.297 and 0.262 nm, corresponding to the (011) and (002) lattice planes in Zn0.3Ce0.2Zr1.8O4 ( Fig. 2(a)). The tetragonal structure of Zn0.3Ce0.2Zr1.8O4 is further confirmed by the selected-area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern and fast Fourier transform (FFT) image (Fig. 2(c, d)) [30,31]. STEM imaging and energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) elemental mapping suggest that Zn, Ce and Zr elements are uniformly and highly dispersed in Zn0.3Ce0.2Zr1.8O4 solid solution (Fig. S2). Statistical analysis of TEM images indicates that the mean size of the Zn0.3Ce0.2Zr1.8O4 solid solution NPs is 6.32 nm (Fig. 2(b)), consistent with the XRD measurement results (Table S1). The SAPO-34 zeolites that are prepared exhibit high crystallinity, and they all have cuboid crystal shapes with a particle size of approximately 1 µm. After powder mixing of the Zn0.3Ce0.2Zr1.8O4 solid solution and SAPO-34 zeolite, the crystal structure of both components is well-maintained (Fig. S3). SEM and TEM images indicate that the Zn0.3Ce0.2Zr1.8O4 solid solution NPs are closely dispersed on the surfaces of SAPO-34 zeolite (Fig. S4). The chemical environment and state of O, Ce and Zr atoms in Zn0.3Ce0.2Zr1.8O4 solid solution are analyzed using XPS. In the Zr(3d)-XPS (Fig. S5a), the binding energy of Zr-3d5/2 (184.3 eV) and Zr-3d3/2 (182.0 eV) of the Zn0.3Ce2−yZryO4 solid solution is down-shifted compared to that of Zn0.3Zr2.0O4 (Fig. S5a)). This is because the incorporation of Ce into the lattice of zirconium oxide can distort the Zr-O bond and modify the electronic properties of Zr [32,33] . Eight peaks are observed in the Ce-3d XPS ( Fig. 3a), indicating the presence of both Ce3+ (883.9 and 902.6 eV) and Ce4+ (881.4, 888.2, 897.2, 900.1, 906.7 and 915.8 eV) species. A deconvolution of the Ce-3d XPS shows that Zn0.3Ce0.2Zr1.8O4 possesses a higher Ce3+/ (Ce3+ + Ce4+) ratio than other Zn0.3CeyZr2−yO4 samples, suggesting that the incorporation of appropriate amounts of Ce generates more defect sites or oxygen vacancies. This is supported by O-1 s XPS (Fig. 3(b)). By deconvolving the spectra, four types of oxygen species are found in Zn0.3CeyZr2−yO4; lattice oxygen (529.3 eV), oxygen atoms around vacancy sites (530.1 eV), surface hydroxyl species (530.8 eV) and oxygen atoms of surface-adsorbed molecular water (532.1 eV) [18]. Using the intensity of the peak at 530.1 eV as a measure to estimate oxygen vacancy content [17], the oxygen vacancy concentration exhibits a volcanic relationship with the Ce/Zr ratio, with the maximum value of 39.5% manifested in Zn0.3Ce0.2Zr1.8O4. This is also supported by the result of Raman that a distinct broad peak was observed at around 627 cm–1 on the Zn0.3Ce0.2Zr1.8O4 solid solution (Fig. S5(b)) [32–37]. Furthermore, the H2-TPR results suggest the detection of a strong reduction peak between 250 and 450 °C, which can be attributed to the reduction of surface Ce species that are coordinated, in an unsaturated manner, with surface oxygen ions [32,38] in the Zn0.3Ce0.2Zr1.8O4 solid solution (Fig. S5(c)). In the CO2-TPD, two major CO2 desorption peaks are observed, where the low temperature (<150 °C, α peak) and high temperature (150–450 °C, β peak) peaks correspond to the physically adsorbed CO2 in bulk phase lattice, and that interacts with the surface O vacancy [18,39], respectively (Fig. S5(d)). All these results demonstrated that the Zn0.3Ce0.2Zr1.8O4 solid solution has abundant surface oxygen vacancies, which are beneficial to promote the formation of methanol-related intermediates and suppress the formation of CO during CO2 hydrogenation [18,23]. 3.2 Catalytic performance To create a highly efficient catalyst that operates at low temperature and low pressure, we briefly explore several factors that significantly affect catalyst’s performance, including catalyst composition, integration manner, temperature, pressure and gas hourly space velocity. As shown in Table 1 and Fig. S6, the Zn0.3Ce0.2Zr1.8O4/SAPO-34 bifunctional catalyst with a high oxygen vacancy concentration shows higher CO2 conversion and C2 = – C4 = selectivity of 6.6% and 68.8%, respectively, but lower CO emission of 10.0% compared to that of Zn0.3Zr2.0O4/SAPO-34 (6.0%, 67.0% and 12.1%, respectively) at 300 ºC and 1.0 MPa. Increasing the content of Ce in Zn0.3CeyZr2−yO4 solid solution can markedly suppress the formation of CO, and the Zn0.3Ce2.0O4/SAPO-34 gives the CO selectivity of only 4.8%, despite decreased CO2 conversion and C2 = – C4 = selectivity. It is noteworthy that the catalytic activity of the Zn0.3CeyZr2−yO4 for CO2 conversion linearly increases with the surface oxygen vacancy concentration (Table S2 and Fig. 4), indicating that O vacancies play a vital role in the reaction process. Besides the Ce/Zr ratio, with the increase of Zn content on ZnxCe0.2Zr1.8O4 solid solution (x = 0.1 – 1.0), the CO2 conversion and the C2 = – C4 = selectivity are slightly increased from 6.3% and 66.2% in Zn0.1Ce0.2Zr1.8O4/SAPO-34–7.3% and 68.5% in Zn1.0Ce0.2Zr1.8O4/SAPO-34 at 300 ºC and 1.0 MPa (Table 1 and Fig. S7). However, the CO selectivity also increases from 9.1% in Zn0.1Ce0.2Zr1.8O4/SAPO-34–14.3% in Zn1.0Ce0.2Zr1.8O4/SAPO-34. The product distribution is significantly affected by the integration method of Zn0.3Ce0.2Zr1.8O4 solid solution and SAPO-34 zeolite. As shown in Fig. S8, powder mixing of Zn0.3Ce0.2Zr1.8O4 solid solution and SAPO-34 zeolite shows much higher C2 = – C4 = selectivity (91.3%) and O/P ratio (31.5) at 300 ºC and 1.0 MPa, but lower selectivity of CH4 (1.5%) and C2 0 – C4 0 (2.9%) than those of granule stacking of these two materials (68.8% for C2 = – C4 = and 4.6 for O/P ratio; 9.5% for CH4 and 14.8% for C2 0 – C4 0). This is because the Zn0.3Ce0.2Zr1.8O4 solid solution and SAPO-34 zeolite are closer in the uniform powder mixture than in the granular mixture, which facilitates the fast transportation of intermediate species within different active sites [21,22]. However, an overly tight contact of Zn0.3Ce0.2Zr1.8O4 solid solution and SAPO-34 zeolite by prolonging the milling time of the two components in an agate mortar for 60 min and then calcining the powder mixture together in one crucible leads to the decrease of C2 = – C4 = selectivity and O/P ratio to 90.1% and 27.9, respectively, due to the secondary hydrogenation of olefins [40]. Meanwhile, it should be noticed that increasing the proximity of bifunctional active sites also promotes the RWGS reaction and the CO selectivity is increased from 10.0% for granule stacking to 16.1% for calcining hybrid. Zn0.3Ce0.2Zr1.8O4/SAPO-34 bifunctional catalyst exhibits high low-temperature catalytic activity for CO2 hydrogenation. At 260 ºC, the CO2 conversion and C2 = – C4 = selectivity can reach 5.3% and 84.3%, respectively, while the CO emission is only 5.6% ( Fig. 5(a)). There is a volcano curve relationship between C2 = – C4 = selectivity and reaction temperature. The C2 = – C4 = selectivity reaches the highest value of 91.3% at 300 ºC (Fig. 5(b)). From a thermodynamic viewpoint, the CO2 hydrogenation to methanol and then conversion of methanol into olefins are exothermic, while the RWGS is a strongly endothermic reaction [41,42]. Therefore, a relatively low temperature is helpful in suppressing the RWGS reaction and favoring the equilibrium moving towards the methanol synthesis direction. Fig. 5(c) suggests that decreasing the reaction pressure can markedly slow down the over-hydrogenation of olefins. At 280 ºC and 0.1 MPa, the selectivity of C2 0 – C4 0 and CO is only 1.1% and 6.9%, respectively, while the C2 = – C4 = selectivity remains 71.2%. This results in an O/P ratio as high as 64.7. The unconverted methanol (including dimethyl ether (DME), around 12%) is largely consumed by slightly increasing the reaction pressure. At 280 ºC and 0.5 MPa, the C2 = – C4 = selectivity and O/P ratio can reach up to 90.1% and 60.1, respectively, while the fraction of unconverted methanol (including DME) is reduced to below 3.0%, with the selectivity of C2 0 – C4 0 and CO only 1.5% and 7.9%, respectively (Fig. 5(d)). Table S3 demonstrates that Zn0.3Ce0.2Zr1.8O4/SAPO-34 has a highly comparable C2 = – C4 = yield (5.0%) to other reported results (4.9 – 7.0%) under these conditions. However, it requires much lower reaction temperature and pressure, effectively reducing the energy consumption during CO2 hydrogenation. The catalytic activity is also influenced by the gas hourly space velocity (GHSV), the relative amounts of Zn0.3Ce0.2Zr1.8O4 solid solution and zeolite, and the acid content of zeolite. Increasing the space velocity results in a marked decrease in selectivity for C2 0 – C4 0 and CO, along with an increase of the O/P ratio ( Fig. 6). At 280 ºC and 0.5 MPa, with GHSV of 9600 mL/(g·h), Zn0.3Ce0.2Zr1.8O4/SAPO-34 exhibits high selectivity for C2 = – C4 = and low selectivity for C2 0 – C4 0 (84.2% and 0.9%, respectively), resulting in an O/P ratio of 93. More importantly, the CO emission is only 4.0%, with CO2 conversion of 5.4%. The Zn0.3Ce0.2Zr1.8O4 solid solution exhibits high methanol selectivity (including DME) of 94.5%, which can be effectively converted into light olefins with the addition of acidic SAPO-34 zeolite (Table S4). Increasing the acid content of SAPO-34, from Si/Al ratio of 0.025–0.15, gradually decreases the amount of unconverted methanol. Furthermore, the formation of alkanes is also effectively suppressed due to the weak acid sites on SAPO-34 zeolite (Table S5) [43]. Zn0.3Ce0.2Zr1.8O4/SAPO-34 bifunctional catalyst also shows good catalytic stability for direct conversion of CO2 into light olefins. At 300 ºC and 0.8 MPa, the catalyst maintains high selectivity for C2 = – C4 = (88%) and high O/P ratio (17), with low selectivities for CH4 (2.5%), C2 0 – C4 0 (5.3%), and CO emission (10%) for at least 100 h (Fig. S9). These results provide strong evidence that the Zn0.3Ce0.2Zr1.8O4/SAPO-34 bifunctional catalyst has great potential as a highly-efficient catalyst for direct conversion of CO2 into light olefins under mild reaction conditions. 3.3 Reaction mechanism The reaction mechanism involved in the direct conversion of CO2 into light olefins over Zn0.3Ce0.2Zr1.8O4 and SAPO-34 composite catalyst was investigated using in situ diffuse reﬂectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS). As shown in Fig. 7(a–c), in the IR spectra, the broad peak at around 1470 − 1530 cm–1 and the shoulder peak at around 1333 cm–1 were assigned to the monodentate and/or bidentate carbonate species formed through CO2 absorption on surface O vacancies [44,45]. Additionally, another two peaks at 1598 and 1374 cm–1, representing the formate species (HCOO*), were quickly detected after reaction for 1 min at 230 °C [46,47]. Meanwhile, the methoxy intermediate (1076 cm–1) was also clearly identified under this condition [48,49]. Similarly, in the region of C−H asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations, the peaks at 2973 and 2878 cm–1, and 2943 and 2825 cm–1, assigned to the formate and methoxy species [44 −49], respectively, were clearly visible, and their concentration gradually increased with reaction time. The variation of relative intensities of formate, carbonate and methoxy species with time on stream was further estimated by integrating their IR peaks at 1598, 1530 + 1470, and 1078 cm–1, respectively. It can be found that the intensities of formate, carbonate and methoxy species are populated rapidly and then stabilize after approximately 7 min (Fig. 7(d)). This illustrates that the CO2 adsorbed on the surface O vacancies of the Zn0.3Ce0.2Zr1.8O4 sample easily interact with the active H* to produce the formate and methoxy species through successive hydrogenations at low temperature and pressure. Similarly, for the reactions at 300 °C, the intensity of the peak at 1598 cm–1 is markedly enhanced while the peaks at 1470 and 1530 cm–1 decline, indicating an increase in the production of formate species (Fig. S10). For the methoxy species, the peak intensity at 1078 cm–1 first increases up to 10 min of reaction and then decreases with further reaction. This can be explained by the fact that the formed methoxy species is quickly converted into methanol at high temperature. The CO2 hydrogenation reaction was also conducted in a pulse-quench reactor with co-feeding H2 and 13C-labelled CO2 (13CO2) at 230 ºC or 300 ºC for 8 min. The trapped species on Zn0.3Ce0.2Zr1.8O4 solid solution were detected by 13C CP/MAS NMR spectra. Fig. 8(a) reveals a strong signal at 167 and 49 ppm, assigned to the formate and methoxy intermediate coordinated to the support [7,50], was distinctly observed at 230 and 300 ºC. Fig. 8(b) illustrates that the formate intermediate was quickly detected after reaction for 1 min at 300 ºC, indicating that CO2 can be easily hydrogenated to form methanol via the formate-methoxy intermediates on Zn0.3Ce0.2Zr1.8O4 solid solution at low temperature. The peak intensity of formate species climbs up and then declines with reaction time, reaching a maximum after 8 min of reaction. These results strongly suggest that CO2 can be directly hydrogenated to form methanol via the formate-methoxy intermediates on Zn0.3Ce0.2Zr1.8O4 solid solution at low temperature, whereas the route of CO2 being transformed into CO via RWGS reaction is significantly suppressed. Furthermore, when using CO as the feedstock, the product distribution on Zn0.3Ce0.2Zr1.8O4/SAPO-34 at 300 °C and 1.0 MPa is different from that observed during CO2 hydrogenation (Fig. S11). This result further implies that while CO is an important intermediate in the formation of CH3OH, CO2 hydrogenation via formate-methoxy intermediates would be a more favorable process at low temperature. This also aligns with recent observations on other catalysts, such as ZnO-ZrO2, Pt/MoOx and Cu/Mo2C catalysts [9, 51–53]. Therefore, the results mentioned above indicate that formate and methoxy intermediates are an important bridge for the direct conversion of CO2 into light olefins on the Zn0.3Ce0.2Zr1.8O4/SAPO-34 bifunctional catalyst. The product distribution during CO2 hydrogenation is similar to that observed during typical MTO reactions on the Zn0.3Ce0.2Zr1.8O4 and SAPO-34 composite catalyst (Table S4). The species retained on the bifunctional catalyst after the reaction were detected by GC-MS, revealing that polymethylbenzenes (polyMBs) are the dominant hydrocarbon pool species formed during the conversion of CO2 to light olefins process (Fig. S12). The bifunctional catalyst composed of Zn0.3Ce0.2Zr1.8O4 solid solution and SAPO-34 zeolite demonstrates excellent catalytic stability for CO2 hydrogenation, as confirmed by the well-preserved crystal structure of the composites even after 30 h of reaction (Fig. S13). SEM and TEM images reveal that Zn0.3Ce0.2Zr1.8O4 solid solution NPs are closely dispersed on the surface of SAPO-34 zeolite (Fig. S14). Moreover, the electronic properties of Ce and Zr in the spent catalyst are highly comparable to those of the fresh sample (Fig. S15). However, the surface area, pore volume and acid content of the catalyst slightly decrease because the formed polyMBs hydrocarbon pool species is confined in the pore channels of SAPO-34 zeolite (Table S5). 4 Conclusions The bifunctional catalyst composed of Zn0.3Ce0.2Zr1.8O4 solid solution and SAPO-34 zeolite demonstrates remarkable low-temperature catalytic activity for the direct conversion of CO2 into light olefins. At 280 ºC and 0.5 MPa, the selectivity of C2 = – C4 = and O/P ratio can reach as high as 90.1% and 60.1, respectively, with CO2 conversion of 6.0%. More importantly, the formation of CH4, C2 0 – C4 0 and CO is markedly restricted, with the selectivity of only 1.3%, 1.5% and 7.9%, respectively. As a result, a highly comparable C2 = – C4 = yield is obtained, in line with other reported results. The use of in situ DRIFTS, 13C CP/MAS NMR with isotopic-labelling technology and GC-MS confirm that CO2 hydrogenation to form methanol via the formate-methoxy intermediates is a preferable process on Zn0.3Ce0.2Zr1.8O4 solid solution at low temperature, whereas the route that CO2 is ﬁrst transformed into CO via RWGS reaction is significantly suppressed. Once methanol is formed, it quickly diffuses into the acid sites of SAPO-34 zeolite and produces light olefins through the hydrocarbon pool (HCP) mechanism. This work provides vital insights into the design and development of a high-efficient bifunctional catalyst for the direct conversion of CO2 into light olefins under mild conditions. coredata.dc:description: Currently, restricting the formation of CO and paraffin by-products at mild reaction conditions, and avoiding the waste of carbon resources remain challenging for CO2 hydrogenation into light olefins. Herein, we constructed a bifunctional catalyst consisting of Zn0.3Ce0.2Zr1.8O4 solid solution and SAPO-34 zeolite. The catalyst shows excellent performance with a high C2 = – C4 = selectivity of 90.1% and an O/P ratio of 60.1 at a CO2 conversion of 6.0% at 280 ºC and 0.5 MPa, while the selectivity of CO is only 7.9%. Various characterization and designed experiment results demonstrate that incorporating appropriate amounts of Ce in Zn0.3ZrOx generates more oxygen vacancies that improve CO2 activation to form formate and methoxy intermediates at low temperature and pressure. This promotes the evolution of these intermediates into light olefins over the SAPO-34 zeolite, enhancing the overall capacity of the bifunctional Zn0.3Ce0.2Zr1.8O4/SAPO-34 composited catalyst in CO2 hydrogenation under mild conditions.
coredata.dc:title: Highly efficient ZnCeZrOx/SAPO-34 catalyst for the direct conversion of CO2 into light olefins under mild reaction conditions
